PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: George McConnell
Address:
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? near homestead
Where had you been living before that? Fort
For how many people did you prepare meals? five
How far was it to your nearest store? 11 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? different brands
In what quantities did you buy it? 500 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.25
How much did you use graham flour? not much
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? 10 miles What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? .75
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Little Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? coffee mill

Name: McConwell, George

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910

For how many people did you prepare meals? 5

How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Homestead
In what quantities did you buy it? 5 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.25
How much did you use graham flour? 1 lb
Whole wheat flour? 1 lb
Was flour milled locally? No
That was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $7.5
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal
Other? Whole Wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 20 x 100 lb bags
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.00
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Royal Crown
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb
At that price? $0.90

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? from milk cows
butter? churn eggs? hen
That was the price of butter? of eggs?
Did you keep eggs for winter? hot?
Did you make butter? yes cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? beef, pork
How did you get fresh meat? from butcher in summer,
in winter we froze the beef
How often did you get fresh meat?
How did you preserve meat? in wine
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? no
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? yes in season what kinds? ducks
For how long? occasionally
What part did fish play in the family diet? no fish
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? fresh
Kinds? suckers

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

The last 25 years there has been a big improvement in containers & wrappings especially the aluminum wrappers.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1910, breakfast oatmeal, honey, bacon, eggs, toast, coffee
dinner potatoes, boiled beef, bread & butter, some green salad
supper some leftover from dinner, & bread & jam

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1910
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

roast Beef, mashed potatoes & gravy, sweet pudding with sauce
those present were our own family & one invited guest
I was age 32 my wife age 25, Mary 4, Carl 2, Edith 10 months
our guest Hans Schmidt 18

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No
16. WRAPPERS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

The last 25 years has been a big improvement in canning and preserving, especially the aluminum cans.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family or guests at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1940, dinner: potato salad, fried pork chops, cornbread, applesauce, new baked corn bread dumplings, kielbasa.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the names. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

nosey Boy, mashed potatoes of garbage, and fried pork chops.

three present were our own family: Mrs. H. B. Smith, age 32; my wife, age 25; young 4, Carl 2, Edith 10 months.

our guests: Hans Schmidt 18

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

These days one could not go to the store and get a meal that took only a few minutes to prepare; one had to start from the ground up.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still have plenty of home canned fruit & vegetables & meat, and always have, but since a locker plant was installed in Conall last year we put some meat in the locker, but I like the canned meat best and it is so handy, when someone stops in.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Please do not get at all active and get a meal that took only a few minutes to prepare, one hearty stair from the ground up.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

We still have plenty of home canned fruit & vegetables, meat, and always have a fresh garden in our small lot. We are fortunate to have the food, but I like the canned meat just as much.
